learning_areas.description: Numerical concepts, counting, patterns, basic arithmetic
Fine motor skills - hand-eye coordination, grip, precision
Gross motor skills - balance, coordination, movement
Written skills, numbers, letters, drawing and tracing

activities.description: Testing knowledge about onesself
Draw a stick figure of yourself with basic features
Move and sing along to songs with guided body actions
Learn how our tongue identifies different tastes using taste buds
Kicking the ball
Build body and breath awareness through gentle yoga techniques
Colour picture sections by matching numbers to colours
Recognition of colour red
Match finger images to the correct number
Cut along dotted lines and glue shapes to complete tasks
Draw objects or follow prompts like "Draw yourself today"
Classify healthy and junk food
Make a Sun with PlayDoh
Trace a continuous path through a maze without lifting the hand
Follow a path without lifting a crayon to reach from A to B
Strengthen observation recall logic and instruction-following skills
Learn to move the body in sync with song lyrics
Players scramble for limited chairs when music stops
Identifying the number "1" and one-to-one correspondence
Recognize understand or write numbers from 1-10
Insert individual pieces into a single puzzle slot
Identify and complete patterns using numbers, letters or objects
Arranging and explaining the order of events from a set of pictures
Arrange pictures in the correct order of events
Comprehension and explanation of a picture
Create shapes using clay with hands or simple tools
Fit 8-10 pieces to form a picture
Finding two objects that are the same
Match the five sense to the sense organ
Recognizing corresponding shapes and placing them into a slot
Understanding biggest and smallest, tallest and smallest
Reciting song lyrics, singing along, and performing actions
Develop vocabulary comprehension sequencing imagination and knowledge
Count beads from 1-10 using the PlayPack bead set
Trace uppercase letters A-E with finger and pencil
Match number tiles with corresponding quantity of beads
Sort shapes by colour and form using playdoh molds
Arrange picture cards to form a simple story
Improve writing readiness through tracing for hand-eye coordination
Matching object to appropriate body part
Understanding tools and their uses
Understand the question and answer in a sentence

students.notes: Social butterfly who thrives in group activities.
Curious learner who enjoys hands-on activities.
Creative child with excellent verbal skills.
Quiet observer with strong visual memory.
Inquisitive mind with lots of questions.
Artistic child with excellent fine motor skills.
Quick learner ready for primary school.

activity_logs.comments: TEST: Good effort, needs more practice

reports.report_body:
TEST REPORT: Student A1 had an excellent session today! They counted beads with confidence and showed great enthusiasm.

Home Activities:
1. Count toys at home from 1 to 10
2. Sort beads by colour using the PlayPack
3. Practice number recognition with number tiles

TEST REPORT: Student A2 showed good progress in counting today. With a bit more practice, they will master numbers 1-10.

Home Activities:
1. Practice counting during daily routines
2. Use beads to make simple patterns
3. Play number matching games with tiles

Rahul is making steady progress with shapes and name work. He shows growing confidence with number tasks and tracing. He enjoys threading beads and making red playdoh shapes. His ball kicking needs more practise, but safe, simple drills will help.

Activity 1: Pattern time with number tiles and red playdoh. Lay out tiles 1 to 5. Make 1 red blob for 1, 2 blobs for 2, and so on. Rahul counts aloud as he places each blob. Repeat to check the pattern.

Activity 2: Bead threading on a lacing strip. Use large beads and a pipe cleaner or thick string. Thread colour sequences or simple counts. Pause for a quick count after each bead.

Activity 3: Trace the letter C and make a red C with playdoh. Roll red playdoh into a curve to form a big C. Trace the C with a finger or pencil on paper.

Activity 4: Safe ball practise. Use a soft rolled up sock ball or small bean bag. Set a gentle target on the carpet and kick toward it with the foot. Do 10 kicks, then rest.

Rahul Mishra
Rahul shows strong skills with shape sorters and he recognises his name and the letter C well. He stays focused and tries his best. He can build confidence with drawing the number 5, threading beads, and recognising the colour red. A gentle ball kick will help with movement skills.

1) Number 5 playdoh trace (15 minutes)
Roll playdoh to form the number 5. Place the number tile 5 beside it and trace the shape with a finger. On paper, copy or draw a large 5 next to the practice.

2) Bead threading pattern (15 minutes)
Thread beads onto a safe string or thick lacing to make a small pattern. Use two colours and count as you thread. When finished, tie ends and name the colours used.

3) Red colour playdoh discovery (15 minutes)
Make two red shapes with playdoh, such as a circle and a heart. Talk about the colour red and point to red items in the room.

4) Gentle ball kick drill (15 minutes)
In a clear space, practise gentle kicks with a soft ball back and forth with a family member or against a wall. Keep movements calm and controlled.

Rahul shows steady progress in shape sorting and naming tasks. He traces the letter C confidently and works well with beads and number tiles. He enjoys playdoh and colour activities, and he can stay focused during these tasks. Ball kicking needs a little extra practice for balance and control.

1) Playdoh name and C tracing (15 minutes)
Form Rahul's name in playdoh: R A H U L. Then roll a separate piece to shape the letter C and trace its curve with a finger. Talk through the letters as you go to reinforce name recognition.

2) Bead threading and counting (15 minutes)
Thread large beads onto a safe string or shoelace. When finished, lay out number tiles 1 to 5 and count the beads aloud. This strengthens fine motor skills and early maths.

3) Shape builders with numbers (15 minutes)
Roll playdoh to make circle, square and triangle shapes. Use number tiles to discuss how many corners each shape has. Match each shape to its number tile to reinforce shape knowledge and counting.

4) Safe kick practice (15 minutes)
Use a rolled up sock or a soft ball in a clear space. Set a small target on the floor and try 5 gentle kicks to reach it. Use number tiles as a simple scoreboard to count the kicks.

TEST_Student A1

Summary:
TEST_Student A1 shows strong fine motor skills in drawing the number 5 and threading beads. They enjoy name games and naming colours, especially red. Shape sorters need a little more practice and tracing the letter C could feel smoother. Ball kicking is progressing and with gentle practice it will become more confident.

Activities:
- Five bead pattern with the number 5 tile: Place the number 5 tile and count five beads, putting one bead beside each count. Say the number aloud as you go.
- Playdoh letter C tracing: Roll playdoh into a curved line to form C. Trace the C with a finger and press another C onto paper to copy the shape.
- Shape sorters with playdoh and beads: Make circle, square and triangle shapes in playdoh. Use beads as counters to show how many corners each shape has; sort by shape on a paper mat.
- Name beads: Write the name in large letters on paper. Trace each letter with a finger, then line up beads to match the letters along the bottom.

Rahul is making solid progress with letters and naming. He traces the letter C well and can recognise his own name. He shows good effort with shape sorters and red colour tasks. A few activities like drawing number 5, threading beads and ball kick could use more practice.

1) Five and playdoh count
15 minutes. Materials: playdoh and the number tile 5.
- Roll 5 small playdoh balls.
- Place the 5 tile beside them and count aloud.
- Talk about the number five as you finish.

2) Bead threading pattern
15 minutes. Materials: large beads and safe string.
- Thread 5-6 beads in two colours to make a simple pattern.
- Count aloud as you thread to ten.
- When done, say the colours you used and what pattern you made.

3) Red colour playdoh art
15 minutes. Materials: red playdoh.
- Roll 3 red balls and flatten into discs.
- Arrange on paper to make a smiley face or simple pattern.
- Talk about the colour red and where you see it.

4) Trace C and name extension
15 minutes. Materials: paper with a large C or a simple name card; pencil; playdoh.
- Trace the letter C with a finger on the page.
- Shape a C in playdoh and press it gently on the paper.
- If available, trace Rahul's name with a finger or a playdoh line.

TEST_Student B1

TEST_Student B1 shows solid progress in tracing the letter C and sorting shapes. They recognise colour red well and complete simple puzzles. Drawing the number 5 is clear with guidance. They will practise threading beads, naming activities and ball kicking with support.

1) Red bead count line: Set out red beads and number tiles 1 to 5. Count aloud as you slide one bead for each number. If you like, compare with a different colour.

2) Playdoh shape sorter: Roll small playdoh shapes. Use number tiles to count sides or corners. Sort shapes into circles, squares and triangles.

3) Make and trace C: Roll playdoh into a curved strip to form the letter C. Use a finger or pencil to trace the C on paper.

4) Name letters and ball drill: Form letters of the name with playdoh and decorate with beads. Then do a short ball kick drill in a clear space with a soft ball, keeping kicks gentle and controlled.

Rahul Mishra shows strong effort with shape sorters and the name activity. He traces the letter C well and handles colour tasks about red with confidence. He counts with number tiles and is making steady progress on bead work and drawing the number 5. Ball kick needs a bit more practice, but home play through PlayPack will support balance and coordination.

1) Red bead count and colour match (approx 15 minutes): Spread beads on a tray. Find all red beads and place them in a small pile. Put a number tile beside the pile to show the count.

2) Playdoh C and shapes (approx 15 minutes): Roll playdoh to form the letter C. Make three shapes: circle, square, triangle. Put a number tile beside each shape to show how many shapes you made.

3) Bead pattern and counting (approx 15 minutes): Create a simple bead pattern such as red, blue, red. Count the beads and show the total with a number tile.

4) Playdoh number 5 practise (approx 15 minutes): Roll playdoh to shape the number 5. Place the number tile 5 beside it. Count five beads and place them near the tile.

TEST_Student A1 summary:
TEST_Student A1 shows strong fine motor skills with drawing number 5 and threading beads, both Excellent. They recognise their name well and can trace the letter C with good control. Colour work is solid and ball kicking is steady, while shape sorters needs practice. Great effort and clear steps to grow in sorting shapes.

1) Number tile path and PlayDoh counters — 15 minutes
- Line up number tiles 1 to 5 on the floor in order.
- For each tile, roll that many PlayDoh balls and place them beside the tile.
- Say the numbers aloud as you go to boost counting.

2) Red beads threading — 15 minutes
- Use safe string and thread 5 red beads.
- Talk about the colour red while threading.
- Tie a simple knot at the end and name red items you see at home.

3) PlayDoh letters and numbers — 15 minutes
- Roll PlayDoh to form the number 5.
- Shape the letter C with PlayDoh.
- Touch and compare the shapes, then press a small trace on paper.

4) Shape sort with PlayDoh — 15 minutes
- Make circle, square and triangle shapes in PlayDoh.
- Write the shape names on small cards.
- Sort the shapes onto the matching label and talk about each shape.

TEST_Student A1 shows strong number and name skills. 
Excellent work drawing number 5 and threading beads. 
Good progress with the colour red and tracing the letter C, and with simple puzzles. 
Shape sorters need more practice; we will build confidence with gentle home activities.

- Count with number tiles and beads: Place number tiles 1 to 5 on the table. Help your child press the same number of beads next to each tile to match the number. This supports counting and number recognition.

- Make a C with playdoh and trace: Roll playdoh into a large C. Use your finger to trace the shape on paper, then press a second C and name the letter.

- Shape sort with playdoh shapes and beads: Create three playdoh shapes circle, square and triangle. Put beads into each shape to practise sorting by name and shape.

- Name in playdoh: Help your child form the letters of their name in playdoh and spell it out.

Rahul shows strong progress with shape sorters and tracing the letter C.  
He recognises his name and works well with beads and colour tasks.  
Ball kicking needs practice, but safe, gentle play will help him improve.

- Shape and count with playdoh and beads: Roll playdoh into a circle, square and triangle. Put a number tile by each shape to show sides. Decorate the shapes with beads for practice.

- Trace C and decorate Rahul: Form a big C from playdoh and trace it with a finger. Use beads to decorate the letters of Rahul on a card.

- Colour pattern and counting: Make a simple pattern using red beads and other colours. Count how many beads you used and show the number with the tiles.

- Ball kick practice: In a safe space, gently kick a soft ball or balloon toward a target on the floor or wall. Count kicks with number tiles.

TEST_Student B1 shows strong number sense and good colour and shape skills. They handle tasks like drawing the number 5, tracing the letter C and using shape sorters with ease. Ball kicking is confident and enjoyable. They would benefit from a little practice threading beads and saying their own name when asked.

Bead threading and number pattern
- Use large beads and a lacing cord. Thread a sequence 1 to 5 beside a number tile for each step. Talk about colours and counting as you go. 15 minutes
- Keep safety in mind and supervise at all times. After finishing, sort beads by colour.

Name practice with playdoh letters
- Roll playdoh to form the letters of their name and say each letter aloud as they press it. 15 minutes
- Place the letters on a tray and point to each letter while saying the name.

Colour and shape play
- Build a red shape with playdoh that matches a shape from the sorter. Count how many shapes you used. 15 minutes
- Talk about the colour red and the shape names as you work.

Trace the letter C
- Trace C on paper with a finger or pencil, then roll a long C with playdoh. 15 minutes
- Finish by naming the letter and its sound.
